importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the CNN article's publication, which covers Sunday's NFL Week 7 games, marking a pivotal moment in the 2025 NFL season with dramatic comebacks and record-breaking performances.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The first seven weeks of the 2025 NFL season, during which 26 lead changes in the final two minutes of regulation occurred—the most in NFL history for that span—highlighting a season defined by volatility and unpredictability.

keyTakeAways: The NFL season has shown increasing unpredictability with 26 lead changes in the final two minutes of regulation through Week 7, the most in history for that period.

The Denver Broncos made history by overcoming a 19-point deficit in the fourth quarter to defeat the New York Giants 33-32, becoming the first team to ever do so after leading by 18 points or more after three quarters.
Second-year quarterback Bo Nix led the Broncos’ comeback, throwing for two touchdowns and rushing for two, while also connecting on a game-winning field goal as time expired.
Green Bay Packers defeated the Arizona Cardinals 27-23 with two fourth-quarter touchdowns and a late turnover on downs, aided by Micah Parsons' dominant defensive performance.

Drake Maye of the New England Patriots broke Tom Brady’s franchise record with a 91.3% completion rate in a 31-13 victory over the Tennessee Titans, becoming the first player in Super Bowl era to achieve 90% completion, over 200 passing yards, and over 50 rushing yards in a single game.
Miami Dolphins’ Tua Tagovailoa was benched in the fourth quarter after throwing three interceptions, including one returned for a touchdown, in a 31-6 loss to the Cleveland Browns.
New York Jets’ Justin Fields was benched at halftime after a poor first half performance, replaced by Tyrod Taylor, who threw two costly interceptions.
The Jets remain winless at 0-7, while the Dolphins are now 1-13 combined with their rivals after losses to the Browns and Panthers.

The article highlights the broader NFL landscape of rising quarterback instability, dramatic comebacks, and high-profile coaching decisions, such as Mike Vrabel's return to a victory with the Patriots, and benchings due to poor performance.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Week 7 of the 2025 NFL season was defined by dramatic comebacks, record-breaking performances, and high-profile coaching decisions. The Denver Broncos made history by overcoming a 19-point deficit in the fourth quarter, becoming the first team to do so after leading by 18 points or more after three quarters, thanks to a standout performance by second-year quarterback Bo Nix. The Green Bay Packers also pulled off a late comeback against the Arizona Cardinals, aided by defensive dominance from Micah Parsons. Meanwhile, New England Patriots quarterback Drake Maye broke Tom Brady’s franchise record with a 91.3% completion rate in a 31-13 win over the Tennessee Titans, becoming the first player in Super Bowl era history to complete 90% of his passes, throw over 200 yards, and rush over 50 yards in a single game. On the downside, the Miami Dolphins and New York Jets suffered significant losses, with Tua Tagovailoa and Justin Fields respectively being benched due to poor performances, highlighting ongoing quarterback instability and roster challenges. The season continues to be marked by volatility, with 26 lead changes in the final two minutes of regulation—the most in NFL history over the first seven weeks.
title: Historic and dramatic comebacks, second-year QB breaks Tom Brady record and high-profile benchings: NFL Week 7 Sunday review
